title: Eduard Hagenbach-Bischoff
text:
Eduard Hagenbach-Bischoff (20 February 1833, in <a href="Basel">Basel</a> – 23 December 1910, in Basel) was a Swiss physicist. The <a href="Hagenbach-Bischoff%20quota">Hagenbach-Bischoff quota</a> (a voting system) is named after him.
The son of the theologian <a href="Karl%20Rudolf%20Hagenbach">Karl Rudolf Hagenbach</a>, he studied physics and mathematics in Basel (with Rudolf Merian), Berlin (with <a href="Heinrich%20Wilhelm%20Dove">Heinrich Wilhelm Dove</a> and <a href="Heinrich%20Gustav%20Magnus">Heinrich Gustav Magnus</a>), Geneva, Paris (with <a href="Jules%20Jamin">Jules Célestin Jamin</a>) and obtained his Ph.D. in 1855 at Basel. He taught at the "Gewerbeschule" (vocational school) in Basel and was after his <a href="habilitation">habilitation</a>, a professor of mathematics at the <a href="University%20of%20Basel">University of Basel</a> for one year.
From 1863 to 1906 he was a full professor of physics at Basel (successor of <a href="Gustav%20Heinrich%20Wiedemann">Gustav Heinrich Wiedemann</a>). In 1874 he became director of the institute of physics at the newly founded “Bernoullianum” in Basel, and from 1874 to 1879 he was president of the <a href="Swiss%20Academy%20of%20Natural%20Sciences">Swiss Academy of Sciences</a>.
Hagenbach-Bischoff was involved in the popularisation of science, and at the “Bernoullianum” he gave more than 100 popular talks, such as one in 1896 on the newly discovered <a href="X%20rays">X rays</a>.
